Award.AbstractNarration:
As our world, with time included, is four dimensional, exploring similarities and differences of 4-dimensional spaces through geometric and topological methods leads to better understanding of the universe we live in. Smooth and symplectic structures on 4-dimensional spaces are broadly featured in theoretical physics; e.g. in classical mechanics, string and quantum field theories. The research projects invoke new ideas and techniques, creating leverage to address several important problems regarding the topology of smooth and symplectic 4-manifolds, and that of contact 3-manifolds and their fillings. A key aspect of this program is the reduction of many intricate problems to fairly simple algebraic relations between curves on surfaces, which sets an excellent ground to present problems accessible to graduate and advanced undergraduate students. The PI will engage and mentor students in related research topics.

This is a project in low dimensional geometry and topology, focusing on a variety of profound questions involving symplectic 4-manifolds and contact 3-manifolds. Some of the projects on 4-manifolds are pertinent to classification of symplectic Calabi-Yau surfaces, diversity of Lefschetz pencils and fibrations, novel constructions of small exotic and symplectic 4-manifolds, and complexity in various stable equivalences. As for 3-manifolds, the PI will probe the complexity in Giroux correspondence in terms of open book support genus, the characterization of newly discovered contact 3-manifolds with arbitrarily large Stein fillings, diversity of complex curves bounding links in the 3-sphere, and generalizations of quasi-positive links. Gauge theory, new mapping class group techniques and symplectic surgeries will play a vital role in this program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI carried out various research projects related to the proposal, several of which were in collaboration with mathematicians in US and abroad. The results are manifested in 20 research articles written or published during this period, and were disseminated in about 40 invited seminar, conference and colloquium talks at more than 25 different institutions. The PI mentored several graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs, who carried out related research projects. The PI co-organized 2 short (2-3 days) and 2 long (5 days) conferences, and has been a co-organizer of a weekly research seminar. 

The PI's research focuses on a variety of profound questions involving symplectic 4-manifolds and contact 3-manifolds. Some of the projects on 4-manifolds are pertinent to classification of symplectic Calabi-Yau surfaces, diversity of Lefschetz pencils and fibrations, novel constructions of small exotic and symplectic 4-manifolds, and complexity in various stable equivalences.

During the grant period, the PI and his collaborators gave several new constructions of symplectic Calabi-Yau surfaces and new exotic rational surfaces through Lefschetz pencils, by introducing new methods to produce interesting mapping class group factorizations. The PI's work with Korkmaz completely settled the genus-2 case. The PI showed that the Donaldson-Gompf correspondence between symplectic 4-manifolds and Lefschetz pencils is a lot more diverse than previously thought, while answering a question of Auroux on surgery equivalence of topologically alike pencils on a given symplectic 4-manifold.The PI and Saeki employed singularity techniques to produce broken Lefschetz fibrations and Gay-Kirby trisections from each other, and discovered a special class of Gay-Kirby trisections. The PI, Monden and Van Horn-Morris completely determined the maximum length of a positive factorization of a boundary multitwists (which correspond to Lefschetz pencils), depending only on genus of the surface and the number o boundary components ---settling completely earlier questions/conjectures of Smith, Auroux, Stipsicz and Ozbagci. In a joint work with Van Horn-Morris, the PI constructed quasipositive 4-braids which bound infinitely many different complex annuli, whereas quasipositive 3-braids are known to bound only finitely many. The PI and Sunukjian proved that any two topologically isotopic surfaces in a 4-manifold become smoothly isotopic after locally and trivially increasing their genera, while showing that for the well-known constructions of exotically knotted surfaces, one stabilization is enough.
